Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: System for Predicting Energy Demands and Energy Usage of Buildings
Award.AbstractNarration:
This I-Corps team has developed tools to forecast energy demands for buildings in cities and for cities as a whole. The application of forecasting energy demands has high commercial value for a range of users including building operators, utility companies, data center managers, and many others to prepare their facilities and/or take advantage of energy savings. The proposed technology can have a large impact on industries and government entities that provide information, management controls, equipment, and energy resources for the built environment by accurate forecasting of their energy demands. Heavily urbanized regions offer some of the greatest opportunities for this technology to have a significant impact across this broad range of applications areas. New control and HVAC technologies may be envisioned that make use of forecasted energy information to optimize their operation.

The proposed concept is based on the existing Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) mesoscale model that considers real time temporal fluctuations of local weather and specific characteristics of buildings, neighborhoods, and cities, including building heights, materials, optical properties,HVAC and energy generation systems used, and usage by occupants. Significant energy savings could be possible due to a range of possible scenarios including but not limited to safety in the grid, anticipated preparation of large HVAC equipment based on refine forecasted weather and/or demand, better planning of production stocks, or long-term energy efficiency planning based on improved understanding of the energy activity of facilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Building energy management can consume a large portion of a business' operational budget.  This issue is exacerbated in demand response markets when peak demand events occur leading to likely additional charges.  During summer, these peak demand events occur in the afternoons, when power is more expensive, and space cooling is at its highest.  Institutional buildings such as universities, hospitals, corporate campuses, and government offices are particularly susceptible to these costs due to their large occupancy rates as well as numerous large buildings.   Under this NSF I-CORPS project, a team of students and faculty explored the market value of energy forecasting tools for demand response markets. 

Through a market discovery effort where more than 90 companies in US and abroad were contacted and interviewed, a deep understanding of the demand response markets needs was possible.  The team narrowed the market value proposition of energy forecasts to a reliable product for building operators and building managers in demand response markets located in large cities.  The market size for improved building energy management is estimated at $20B and growing very rapidly. The market need is for a reliable and low cost energy forecast solution at the individual buildings with future window of 24 hrs or longer. 

The team developed and tested a system to forecast energy demands up to 72 hrs in advance with no required hardware installation.  The developed system forecasts energy demands days ahead for single buildings, neighborhood and cities.  These energy forecasts are obtained through novel use of high resolution weather models adapted to consider the interaction between the thermal and mechanical effects of the urban environment taking into account the anthropogenic heat contributions due to indoor-outdoor energy and mass exchanges. As a result, it is possible to predict, at a single instance and without reliance of on-site installed instruments, the weather and energy demands (in W/m2 or kWh) for a single building, an entire neighborhood or a city.  This is more effective in cities where weather is a major driver of the peak demands (i.e. large loads due to heating, ventilation, and air conditioning, [HVAC]). The information is provided at temporal resolutions that can vary from minutes to days, and spatial resolutions from few meters to a few kilometers in 2D or 3D. Preliminary testing of this method in New York City was successful when benchmarking results with a large number of environmental sensors across the city and a few selected buildings.  This technology approach could empower buildings facilities managers to optimize their resources, allowing them to better manage manpower and resources to handle peak loads including the possibility of "getting off the grid" whenever they expect increased costs due to peak demand events. 

With worldwide demand response programs increasing and the continued trend in warmer summers inducing higher demand peaks, this I-CORPS project opened the opportunities to support stakeholders to reduce their operational costs with minimal onsite footprint.  The prospect technical solution has the ability to serve any building in any given city allowing to scale fast and with few technical barriers taking advantage of the growing need for energy management at the building level.
